articles.headline: An Arkansas Community Looks for an Execution to End Its Ache
articles.snippet: No case connected to the state’s recent spate of executions was more locally resonant than the one involving Cecil Boren, whose killer, Kenneth D. Williams, was executed on Thursday night.
articles.abstract: No case connected to the state’s recent spate of executions was more locally resonant than the one involving Cecil Boren, whose killer, Kenneth D. Williams, was executed on Thursday night.
articles.lead_paragraph: STAR CITY, Ark. — James Hawkins, the affable local coroner, has long performed a grim duty on execution nights: He pronounces the deaths of the condemned prisoners. He has done it more than two dozen times.
articles.byline: By Alan Blinder and Manny Fernandez

articles.headline: Cloud Produces Sunny Earnings at Amazon, Microsoft and Alphabet
articles.snippet: The impact on quarterly results announced Thursday was particularly acute at Amazon, far and away the leader in online computing services.
articles.abstract: The impact on quarterly results announced Thursday was particularly acute at Amazon, far and away the leader in online computing services.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The moneymaking machines at the core of Amazon, Microsoft and Alphabet, the parent company of Google, are notably different. But the respective kings of online retailing, software and internet search should all credit a relatively new line of business for lifting their financial results.
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield, David Streitfeld and Steve Lohr

articles.headline: Republicans’ Fiscal Discipline Wilts in Face of Trump’s Tax Plan
articles.snippet: Some G.O.P. lawmakers are rallying around the idea that less taxation is more important than less debt, in a break from their party’s vocal deficit hawks.
articles.abstract: Some G.O.P. lawmakers are rallying around the idea that less taxation is more important than less debt, in a break from their party’s vocal deficit hawks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — From an office high above Manhattan, the billionaire Peter G. Peterson has warned for years that the federal government is borrowing too much money. So have other Republican grandees, like former Senator Alan K. Simpson, who made dire predictions about the federal debt in a 2010 report. Republicans in Congress have been eager to sing from the same hymnal so long as a Democrat was in the White House.
articles.byline: By Binyamin Appelbaum, Alan Rappeport and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: Trump Tax Plan Would Shift Trillions From U.S. Coffers to the Richest
articles.snippet: The vast majority of benefits would go to the highest earners and largest holders of wealth, analysts said, setting up a battle over the government’s strained resources.
articles.abstract: The vast majority of benefits would go to the highest earners and largest holders of wealth, analysts said, setting up a battle over the government’s strained resources.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s proposal to slash individual and business taxes and erase a surtax that funds the Affordable Care Act would amount to a multitrillion-dollar shift from federal coffers to America’s richest families and their heirs, setting up a politically fraught battle over how best to use the government’s already strained resources.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Patricia Cohen

articles.headline: Sean Hannity Defends Executive as Fox News Turmoil Continues
articles.snippet: Mr. Hannity said on Twitter that someone at the network was trying to fire its co-president Bill Shine, whom he called “an innocent person.”
articles.abstract: Mr. Hannity said on Twitter that someone at the network was trying to fire its co-president Bill Shine, whom he called “an innocent person.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Swirling tensions at Fox News burst into public view on Thursday as one of its stars, Sean Hannity, spoke out in defense of an embattled executive at the center of an expanding culture clash inside the network.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Emily Steel

articles.headline: As College Deadlines Near, Families Wonder What They Can Pay
articles.snippet: College choices are due soon. How do you get the best financial aid package, and what are the trade-offs?
articles.abstract: College choices are due soon. How do you get the best financial aid package, and what are the trade-offs?
articles.lead_paragraph: This month, the New York State Legislature made the state the first in the nation to make tuition at the state’s public colleges and universities free for many full-time undergraduates from families with income under $100,000 per year. The cutoff will rise soon to $125,000.

articles.headline: Time Inc. Decides Not to Sell Itself
articles.snippet: The company said it would remain independent and would pursue its strategic plan of digital growth and new revenue opportunities.
articles.abstract: The company said it would remain independent and would pursue its strategic plan of digital growth and new revenue opportunities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Time Inc. has decided to go it alone, choosing a path filled with challenges that no legacy publisher has completely mastered.

articles.headline: G.D.P. Report Shows U.S. Economy Off to Slow Start in 2017
articles.snippet: The government said gross domestic product grew at an annual rate of 0.7 percent in the first quarter, a three-year low, as consumer spending let up.
articles.abstract: The government said gross domestic product grew at an annual rate of 0.7 percent in the first quarter, a three-year low, as consumer spending let up.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans say they feel more optimistic about the economy since President Trump was elected. But they certainly are not acting that way, and that is shaping up to be a challenge for his administration.

articles.headline: Trump on North Korea: Tactic? ‘Madman Theory’? Or Just Mixed Messages?
articles.snippet: The White House has been sending different signals to Kim Jong-un, a master at keeping his adversaries unsettled.
articles.abstract: The White House has been sending different signals to Kim Jong-un, a master at keeping his adversaries unsettled.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was only a few hours after his secretary of state cracked open the door on Thursday to negotiating with the North Koreans that President Trump stepped in with exactly the kind of martial-sounding threats against the country that the White House, until now, had carefully avoided.
